It's a hammer, but not everything is a nail, right?
So together with our partners, an extensive discovery, we came up with a set of challenges that.

Let's say could be addressed with artificial intelligence, and in general we can say that they are like two groups of challenges that that we have identified in manufacturing companies 11 group coming from outside the company, an one inside the company.

That means that companies manufacturing companies are Preston.

How much I'm going to actually sell to my client?

Unrealistic normatives for production plans.

Dependency on individuals.

So it's not been exposed to risks.

To the finish line on time.

What is the best thing to do right now?
To run whatif analysis to run simulations every simulations, what would be the best thing to do right now?
How it works?

If we imagine ourselves collectively as a as a machine, it would look like this.

We need more and more data and this data is then utilized to build a digital twin utilizing artificial intelligence and then building a digital twin.

Then we use these digital twin together with real time data from the same sources as we did for building this digital twin, and then we conceive forecasts that we communicate through dashboards in the form of insights, alerts, informations.
We pass this to people and people, make actions, actions on the shop floor in real time.
So there are two objectives here.
First, we want to shorten response time.
Now and we want to prepare for things that are going to happen in the future.

What we have added here for the status of the factory is a little bit of artificial intelligence telling certain operators.

So then more information can follow by clicking on this information.
The next.

One is understanding why do I have a problem right now supporting this with intelligent alerts and based on our previous projects we can do that utilizing digital twin Fresh data and then prioritize these alerts based on their impact on KPI KPI.
Sorry on the bottom line or the company, so based on that we can reduce the number of alerts because we can.

Used to it so like wearing or wearing a ring on your finger.
You would get crazy if you would feel it all the time right?

So ideas here is that you reduce the number of alerts and also we can target these alerts to people that can take action because they are the closest to the problem or it's their responsibility to do so and these alerts are working in this very situation right now so we can understand why do we have a problem when we can solve it.
An also sink into the future where the problem will occur.

We have that in manufacturing companies but these plans in in general are billed based on assumptions.
An based on theory.
Of course, also buy a lot of.
Let's say expertise an an experience, but they they are tuned all the time in real time.
They are tuned by phone calls by emails by 1 to one communication.
What we have done here we have utilized artificial intelligence to improve that part forecasting.

A on a production line.
Player production line two with Jaune and Jaune on the production line and with that kind of raw material.
So we used actually historical data to do these predictions.
And these plans are up to date.
So because we all the time take fresh data from the shop floor and we make predictions and we can run simulations to make these plans optimal and insightful in terms of if something goes wrong.
What is the best thing to do right now?
Let's run few simulations and will finish right there.
So benefits.
How?
How can it help?
Because we improve the information transfer with with the usage of collector lip, we have saved one day per week for planners and for team coordinators.
We can predict organizational downtime three days ahead.
And especially interesting for assembly lines is reducing production time for 10% on account of giving people to work on things or product that they are the best at.
And bottom line, improving overall efficiency by 5%.
Thank you very much.
